required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Physiological Phenotyping of Respiratory Outcomes in Infants Born Premature
clinical_study.official_title: Physiological Phenotyping of Respiratory Outcomes in Infants Born Premature

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to examine if infants are more likely to suffer from respiratory complications during their first year of life due to being born premature.

detailed_description.textblock: The overall objective of this study is to determine if infant respiratory morbidities after preterm birth are highly variable due to differential impairment of airway, parenchymal and vascular development that can be characterized as distinct physiologic phenotypes. If the nature and severity of these specific impairments of lung function are strongly associated with increased respiratory morbidities during infancy and that proteomic biomarkers can enhance the physiologic characterization of phenotype and prediction of late respiratory outcomes.

primary_outcome.measure: Infant lung development measured by diffusion lung capacity (DLCO).
primary_outcome.description: To characterize respiratory phenotypes through specific physiologic measures that quantify and identify predominant small airways, parenchymal and vascular dysfunction at 4 months CA and determine whether these phenotypes define risks for late respiratory morbidity during infancy.

arm_group.description: Premature infants born between 24+0 and 36+6 weeks of gestation.

intervention.intervention_name: Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide (DLCO)

study_pop.textblock: Recruiting infants born between 24+0 and 36+6 weeks gestational age

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Infants born to mothers who are between the gestational ages of 24+0 and 36+6 weeks.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Cardiopulmonary defects
- Chromosomal defects
- Structural abnormalities of the upper airway, chest wall, or lungs
- Neurological/Neuromuscular disorders
- Infant not considered viable
- Family unlikely to be available for long term follow up
- Mothers under the age of 18.
- Non English speaking
